entry.title: rock-and-wave (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the dollar pattern (example pictured) in Turkish Iznik pottery is a variant of the rock-and-wave border pattern adapted from Chinese porcelain?

entry.title: Jane Dempsey Douglass (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Jane Dempsey Douglass became the first woman to head a worldwide communion of churches in 1990?

entry.title: There's a Blind Man Playin' Fiddle in the Street (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the 1968 single "There's a Blind Man Playin' Fiddle in the Street" by Tages was inspired by an old man that could be seen roaming around the streets of Gothenburg, playing a violin?

entry.title: Kurnianingrat (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Kurnianingrat helped historian George McTurnan Kahin smuggle speeches by leaders of the Indonesian revolution from the Dutch?

entry.title: Lambs Club Building (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Ethel Barrymore and Luisa Tetrazzini reportedly visited the Lambs Club Building even though women were not allowed to access the clubhouse's upper floors?

entry.title: Igor Mangushev (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in August 2022, Igor Mangushev spoke on a stage in a Russian nightclub with what he said was the skull of a Ukrainian soldier killed in the Azovstal Iron and Steel Works?

entry.title: Capitol Hill Citizen (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Capitol Hill Citizen's motto, "Democracy Dies in Broad Daylight", is intended as a jab at The Washington Post's motto, "Democracy Dies in Darkness"?

entry.title: Paul Harvey (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Paul Harvey improvised a viral piano piece using only four notes?
